seg.seg: ... together with Arhats having (cut off) their topknots, ... his father the king Śuddhodana, his mother (Gautamī), ...
he went to the city (of Kapilavastu). At that time the Śākya nobles set up a rule: Whenever Buddha-god (the teacher) ...
(a woman) is not to come. Then Buddha-god the teacher preached the Law for the ﬁrst time, eight(y
thousand) ... (Śākyas) attained the glory. He preached for the third time, [and] forty thousand Śākyas attained the glory. Eighteen (myriads) ...
not a single Śākya woman had attained the glory. Having seen that, the Śākya women ...
they came to each other and complained: Why did Buddha-god the teacher (preach) the Law only to men?
the Śākya women got together, [and] paid respect to Mahāprajāpatī Gautamī.
... has Buddha-god the teacher arisen in the world. But now he does not preach the Law to us.
... to see. Make an effort so that we have a chance to listen to the good Law, (and to see) Buddha-god the teacher.
Make an effort so that we get to hear the good law, (and see) the Buddha, the teacher. (cf 151)
Very quickly she informed the king of the Śākyas. The lord of the Śākyas, king Śuddhodana, also this ...
Listen to the Law! On some days to be sure the women will do the listening. Then, the Śākya women ...
Thus women may surely hear (it) as from today. (cf 151)
... (the women) having obtained the opportunity to hear the Law, (came) in large crowds, vying with each other, (from the city of) Kapilavastu ...
In the meantime, the Śākyas who had obtained the glory, went past the women with concern. The (Śākya young men) who ...
... (having met the women), they said repeatedly: Where are you going, oh women? For you, (there is no possibility) whatsoever to hear the Law.
(the women) say: How that? || The Śākyas say: He speaks in such a way: Of the black (venomous serpent) ...
... to see (?) ..., sleepy, with forked tongues they are, quickly ...

p.note: This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 2a4-3a5. See also 196-7.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 154.

The conﬂict in meaning between this line and MaitrHami 3, 2 a4 may be resolved by reconstructing (sne ja)tilṣinäs ‘without topknot’ (or with ‘cut off’ as the ﬁrst part of a compound form). The last line of our leaf corresponds to MaitrHami 3, 3 a6.
r[i]yac: a trace of the i-diacritic can be seen on the photo in 356 (Michaël Peyrot).
klopiññānt: the denominative verb klop-iññ- is attested here for the ﬁrst time.
TA kumpa-kump and kropa-krop appear to express different aspects of crowding; if kumpa-kump is derived from kump ‘pot’, it must be used here in a metaphorical sense.
This form, which modiﬁes probably a form of TA ārṣal ‘serpent’, is the ﬁrst attestation of a feminine genitive singular of an adjectival -nt- stem, cf. 155-156.

This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 2a4-3a5. See also [[Pinault 1999]]: 196-7.

The translation and the following commentary are adapted from [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 154.

a1 ... together with Arhats having (cut off) their topknots, ... his father the king Śuddhodana, his mother (Gautamī), ... a2 he went to the city (of Kapilavastu). At that time the Śākya nobles set up a rule: Whenever Buddha-god (the teacher) ... a3 (a woman) is not to come. Then Buddha-god the teacher preached the Law for the ﬁrst time, eight(y a4 thousand) ... (Śākyas) attained the glory. He preached for the third time, [and] forty thousand Śākyas attained the glory. Eighteen (myriads) ... a5 not a single Śākya woman had attained the glory. Having seen that, the Śākya women ... a6 they came to each other and complained: Why did Buddha-god the teacher (preach) the Law only to men? a7 the Śākya women got together, [and] paid respect to Mahāprajāpatī Gautamī. a8 ... has Buddha-god the teacher arisen in the world. But now he does not preach the Law to us. b1 ... to see. Make an effort so that we have a chance to listen to the good Law, (and to see) Buddha-god the teacher. b2 Very quickly she informed the king of the Śākyas. The lord of the Śākyas, king Śuddhodana, also this ... b3 Listen to the Law! On some days to be sure the women will do the listening. Then, the Śākya women ... b4 ... (the women) having obtained the opportunity to hear the Law, (came) in large crowds, vying with each other, (from the city of) Kapilavastu ... b5 In the meantime, the Śākyas who had obtained the glory, went past the women with concern. The (Śākya young men) who ... b6 ... (having met the women), they said repeatedly: Where are you going, oh women? For you, (there is no possibility) whatsoever to hear the Law. b7 (the women) say: How that? || The Śākyas say: He speaks in such a way: Of the black (venomous serpent) ... b8 ... to see (?) ..., sleepy, with forked tongues they are, quickly ...

a2. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 2 a10f.

a6. klopiññānt: the denominative verb klop-iññ- is attested here for the ﬁrst time.

b4. TA kumpa-kump and kropa-krop appear to express different aspects of crowding; if kumpa-kump is derived from kump ‘pot’, it must be used here in a metaphorical sense.
